Marina has a perfect life. Three beautiful children (I imagine them güeritos) a good husband, understanding, decent, supportive, wealthy financier. And "the one she finds is because she seeks" and Marina found it in a man with a macho smell who makes her know the most secret and forbidden corners of her sexuality and who also loves her. He's smart, an outstanding writer, and she falls in love. José Cuauhtémoc has only one drawback; he is a confessed parricide locked up in the Oriente Prison and there, in "malandrotitlán", among criminals, corruption, murders, hatred, revenge, love ends, somehow triumphing and the choreographer finds her soul. 4.5/5As all Adam Silvera’s novels, History Is All You Left Me is a contemporary with a roller-coaster of emotions, words left unsaid, forced goodbyes, grief and overcoming the pain.Griffin is dealing with the sudden loss of his ex-boyfriend, Theo. The format in which is written allows us to know about what’s happening in the present, and at the same time, what happened in the past; how their relationship began, how it grew and how they fell each other apart.Griffin and Theo were each other’s first times in so many things, but they were also best friends, so the pain that comes with the loss, is even bigger. Theo represented a light in so many people’s lives that it’s unbelievable he’s gone. And as you probably imagine, not being able to say goodbye to the people we love, brings all sorts of awful feelings that are hard to deal with. Truth is, we deal with the loss in different ways, but one thing for sure is that friends and family can help us heal ourselves, and little by little we can get back on the horse.Still, Griffin is hard on himself because he feels guilty, abandoned, and yes, angry at Theo for leaving him alone even if what happened was an accident. And to put the cherry on top, Jackson, Theo’s current boyfriend, is there too. So it was obvious they don’t get along at the beginning. But eventually, they’re the only ones that understand their pain, so through hits and misses, they overcome the pain that Theo left behind.Grieving is so different from all of us. And this novel moved me in a way that it was hard to process. I've been seeing myself a lot in Griffin because two years ago, I lost the one I've loved the most, and I didn’t have the chance to say goodbye… that brought me to a dark place I've been trying to overcome, so I truly know the struggle he was dealing with. Even as an adult, sometimes life hits you so hard you can barely breathe.Some people say Griffin is selfish, and he truly is, but can you blame him? He’s a teenager that not only lost the love of his life, he also lost a best friend, and there are a lot of emotions to deal with in the first place. Talking about my own experience, we often do reckless things when we are grieving and don’t know how to cope with what we are feeling. Although, I don’t accept nor encourage his actions, I do get where he’s coming from.Anyway, I love contemporaries that make me feel all sorts of things because they feel real, and Adam Silvera is the perfect author for that. He makes me think that life should not be taken for granted, and that we often lose time with hard feelings towards others. There are a lot lessons to be learned in this book, and even though it also takes you to a dark place, it somehow brings hope. For example, I loved the fact that we see them accept Theo’s death, and in the end, they’re in a state of mind where they can say “OK, I lost you. But I cannot be bleeding all the time for you. I gotta take care of myself too.” And that’s a hard step to take, believe me.And also, something that probably doesn’t get called on is that Griffin deals with OCD. I don't struggle the same way he did, but I completely understand how he feels towards some silly things that must be in certain order. So, I'm grateful that an author takes notes of this.I would totally recommend this book even if you're not into YA. Believe me when I tell you, this is a true gem. Adam Silvera has become one of my favorite authors! I can’t wait to read his next work!
